title: NIPS_2016_560_abs

sentences.text: Joint matrix triangularization is often used for estimating the joint eigenstructure of a set M of matrices , with applications in signal processing and machine learning .

We consider the problem of approximate joint matrix triangularization when the matrices in M are jointly diagonalizable and real , but we only observe a set M ' of noise perturbed versions of the matrices in M .
Our main result is a first-order upper bound on the distance between any approximate joint triangularizer of the matrices in M ' and any exact joint triangularizer of the matrices in M .
The bound depends only on the observable matrices in M ' and the noise level .
In particular , it does not depend on optimization specific properties of the triangularizer , such as its proximity to critical points , that are typical of existing bounds in the literature .
To our knowledge , this is the first a posteriori bound for joint matrix decomposition .
We demonstrate the bound on synthetic data for which the ground truth is known .

summary: Joint matrix triangularization is often used for estimating the joint eigenstructure of a set M of matrices , with applications in signal processing and machine learning . We consider the problem of approximate joint matrix triangularization when the matrices in M are jointly diagonalizable and real , but we only observe a set M ' of noise perturbed versions of the matrices in M . Our main result is a first-order upper bound on the distance between any approximate joint triangularizer of the matrices in M ' and any exact joint triangularizer of the matrices in M . The bound depends only on the observable matrices in M ' and the noise level . In particular , it does not depend on optimization specific properties of the triangularizer , such as its proximity to critical points , that are typical of existing bounds in the literature . To our knowledge , this is the first a posteriori bound for joint matrix decomposition . We demonstrate the bound on synthetic data for which the ground truth is known .

Predicate-is_used_for_estimating.label: is used for estimating
Predicate-is_used_for_estimating.description: The predicate 'is used for estimating' indicates that the subject (a method or process) is employed to calculate, approximate, or determine the value of the object (typically an unknown quantity or property). This connection implies that the subject plays a crucial role in obtaining information about the object, which may involve simplification, approximation, or refinement.

Predicate-consider.label: consider
Predicate-consider.description: To consider a predicate as connecting two entities by mentally evaluating or examining one's thoughts about another entity. This connection implies that the subject has given thought to, reflected on, or pondered over the object.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' indicates a state of being or equivalence between two entities. It connects the subject to itself by affirming that they share a common property, characteristic, or quality.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' establishes an identification or equivalence relationship between its subject and object. It indicates that the subject refers to, represents, or has a specific quality or characteristic described by the object.

Predicate-demonstrate.label: demonstrate
Predicate-demonstrate.description: To demonstrate means to show or illustrate something through evidence, examples, or proof. It implies a connection between the subject and object where the subject provides insight into the nature of the object by presenting it in a way that makes its characteristics or properties clear.

Predicate-introduce.label: introduce
Predicate-introduce.description: To introduce means to bring forth or present something, often with a sense of formalization or official recognition. It implies connecting the subject (the entity introducing) with an idea, concept, method, or result that is being presented for consideration or acceptance.

Predicate-provide.label: provide
Predicate-provide.description: To provide means to offer or make available something (e.g. information, resources, constraints) that enables or facilitates an action, process, or understanding between the subject and object. It implies a sense of enabling or supporting the relationship between them.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates that the subject offers or furnishes something (the object), often implying a connection between the two. In general, it suggests that the subject has made available, offered, or given rise to the object in some way.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is related to or encompasses the object at a higher level of abstraction. It suggests that the subject provides a more general context, category, or framework within which the object can be understood.
